newsitem.title: USA: AOL stock rises on analyst upgrade, bullish view.
newsitem.headline: AOL stock rises on analyst upgrade, bullish view.

text.p: The stock of America Online Inc. surged Wednesday after an analyst raised his rating on the world's largest online service, expressing enthusiasm for America Online.
America Online stock rose $2.25 to $34.875 on the New York Stock Exchange in heavy trading of more than 5.7 million shares. It was one of the most actively traded stocks on the exchange.
The stock climbed after Cowen & Co. analyst Jamie Kiggen lifted his rating from neutral to buy and set a 12-month price target of $55 for AOL shares.
Kiggen expressed "unwavering enthusiasm for the AOL story."

The analyst said he believed investors will increasingly recognise the Dulles, Va.-based online service's ability to sustain growth in the number of subscribers, increase non-subscription revenue and become profitable over the next few quarters.

Kiggen said that he believes AOL's recent hiring of Bob Pittman to lead the company's core services business was a positive move because Pittman appeared to have the experience and insight needed to help AOL Chairman Steve Case "achieve his vision of the new AOL."
Kiggen also said the company's new flat-rate pricing of $19.95 a month should have an immediate effect on a number of key measures of the business, especially subscriber growth.
With 7 million subscribers, America Online is the largest online service in the world.
